body.p: A basic HTML template consists of a header, a footer and a stylesheet. Typical PHP applications include header and footer template files individually. Agavi has a better way of doing things through use of its layered output facility.

So far we've only seen Views that output the complete web page and every template we used contained the full HTML header and footer. Obviously, this is no way to maintain templates in a serious application. To dress Bloggie in a new visual layout, we'll rip out the old static templates and replace them with a new skin that'll be applied to the future enhancements as well.

To skin Bloggie, we'll need a number of things: the design templates themselves, some changes to Bloggie configuration, and adjustment of the current templates to the new conventions. In the following sections, we'll see how to do just that.
body.note: In general, dressing up the application after it's been developed is a tedious and error prone procedure even though Agavi makes it significantly easier. Going backwards to undo previous work is a tedious waste of time and its best to prepare everything beforehand.

section.title: Notes on templates
section.p: The end result of the manipulations in this chapter is the "stage 3" Bloggie application. It uses the open source Blue Sky template by Arcsin, which can be obtained from the bluesky/ directory of this tutorial.

Note that Bloggie's administrative section of our "stage 3" application (contained wholly in the Admin module) uses a different set of templates to show off a different skin in the same application. The dressing procedure for the Admin module is very similar and so isn't described in this tutorial.
